storyContent.tagHTML: Around 300 B.C., during the reign of the greedy King Dhanänand of Magadh, lived a Prime Minister named Shaktäl. He had two sons, the ambitious Shriyäk and the brilliant but unambitious Sthulibhadra. While his brother pursued a political career, Sthulibhadra fell in love with a beautiful and famous dancer named Koshä. At the age of 18, he abandoned his family and career to live with her, spending twelve years infatuated by a life of worldly pleasure.

Political turmoil grew, and King Dhanänand became deeply suspicious of his ministers. To prove his other son Shriyäk's loyalty, Shaktäl sacrificed his own life in a tragic plot. When Sthulibhadra learned of his father's death, it shattered his world. He looked at himself in the mirror and, for the first time, saw the waste of his past twelve years. This shocking event sparked a profound realization about the temporary nature of life and pleasure, and he decided to seek a path of lasting happiness.

He refused a high position in the king's court, left Koshä, and went to Ächärya Sambhutivijay, the sixth successor to Bhagawän Mahävir, and begged to be accepted as a monk. Seeing his determination, the Ächärya accepted him.

Sthulibhadra dedicated himself to the ascetic life with great zeal. When the four-month monsoon season arrived, he and three other monks chose to test their spiritual resolve under the most adverse conditions. While others chose to stay near a lion's den or a snake's hole, Sthulibhadra made the most daring request: to spend the monsoon in the picture gallery of his former lover, Koshä.

Koshä, happy to see him again, tried everything to win him back. But Sthulibhadra's faith was unshakeable. He remained deep in meditation, unaffected by her beauty or the seductive art around him. His determination was so powerful that by the end of the four months, he had not only passed his test but had also inspired Koshä to become his disciple. When the monks reconvened, the Ächärya declared Sthulibhadra's victory over his inner demons as the greatest achievement of all.

Years later, a great famine struck, and knowledge of the sacred Jain scriptures began to be forgotten. Sthulibhadra took on the monumental task of preserving them. He learned eleven of the twelve Anga Ägams from the monks who remained. For the final and most complex scripture, he journeyed to Nepal to learn from Ächärya Bhadrabähu, the last person with complete knowledge of the scriptures.

While learning, Sthulibhadra once misused a miraculous power to impress his sisters. Disappointed, Ächärya Bhadrabähu initially refused to teach him the meaning of the final four sections (Purvas). Though he was eventually taught the words, the condition was that he could not pass on their meaning. Because of his great efforts in preserving the scriptures, Sthulibhadra's name is remembered with reverence.

events.title: A Life of Indulgence
events.description: The brilliant Sthulibhadra, son of Prime Minister Shaktäl, leaves home at age 18 to live with the dancer Koshä, spending 12 years in a life of pleasure.

events.title: A Father's Sacrifice
events.description: Amid political turmoil under King Dhanänand, Shaktäl sacrifices his life to secure his other son's position and loyalty.

events.title: The Awakening
events.description: His father's tragic death forces Sthulibhadra to confront the emptiness of his life. He decides to renounce the world.

events.title: Accepting Discipleship
events.description: He goes to Ächärya Sambhutivijay and is accepted as a monk, dedicating himself fully to the spiritual path.

events.title: The Daring Choice
events.description: To test his self-control, Sthulibhadra chooses to spend the four-month monsoon season in the picture gallery of his former lover, Koshä.

events.title: Triumph Over Temptation
events.description: He successfully resists all of Koshä's attempts to win him back, remaining steadfast in his meditation. His victory is hailed as a monumental spiritual achievement.

events.title: The Great Famine
events.description: A 12-year famine causes knowledge of the scriptures to fade. Sthulibhadra convenes a council to recompile them.

events.title: Learning from the Master
events.description: He travels to Nepal to learn the final parts of the scriptures from Ächärya Bhadrabähu, the last living master of all 14 Purvas.

events.title: A Lesson in Power
events.description: After misusing a miraculous power, Sthulibhadra is taught the final scriptures but is forbidden from passing on their full meaning.

charactersData.name: Ächärya Sthulibhadra
charactersData.description: A brilliant young man who spent 12 years living a life of pleasure before a family tragedy awakened him. He became a monk renowned for his immense self-control and played a crucial role in preserving the Jain scriptures after a great famine.

charactersData.name: Koshä
charactersData.description: A beautiful and famous dancer in Pätliputra with whom Sthulibhadra lived for 12 years. She later became his disciple after failing to tempt him back to his old life.

charactersData.name: Ächärya Sambhutivijay
charactersData.description: The head of the Jain order who recognized Sthulibhadra's potential and accepted him as a monk.

charactersData.name: Ächärya Bhadrabähu
charactersData.description: The last person with complete knowledge of all the Jain scriptures (Shrut-kevali). He taught the final, most secret parts of the Ägams to Sthulibhadra in Nepal.

charactersData.name: Shaktäl
charactersData.description: Sthulibhadra's father and the former Prime Minister of Magadh. He tragically sacrificed his own life to ensure his other son's political safety.

quizData.question: Who was Sthulibhadra's father, the Prime Minister of Magadh?
What was the name of the dancer with whom Sthulibhadra lived for 12 years?
What event served as the catalyst for Sthulibhadra's decision to renounce the world?
quizData.answer: The tragic death of his father.

quizData.question: Who was the Ächärya who accepted Sthulibhadra as a disciple?
Where did Sthulibhadra choose to spend his first monsoon season as a monk to test his self-control?
quizData.answer: In the picture gallery of Koshä's residence.

quizData.question: How did the other monks react when the Ächärya praised Sthulibhadra's feat as the greatest?
What happened when another monk tried to repeat Sthulibhadra's test the next year?
quizData.answer: He failed, succumbing to temptation and breaking his monastic vows.

quizData.question: What major disaster made it necessary to recompile the Jain scriptures?
quizData.answer: A great famine that lasted for twelve years.

quizData.question: Who was the last monk to have complete knowledge of all 14 Purvas?
Where did Sthulibhadra have to travel to learn the final scripture (the twelfth Anga Ägam)?
How did Sthulibhadra misuse his newly acquired powers?
quizData.answer: He transformed his body into a lion to impress (or scare) his sisters who were visiting.

quizData.question: What was the consequence of Sthulibhadra misusing his power?
quizData.answer: Ächärya Bhadrabähu refused to teach him the meaning of the last four Purvas.

quizData.question: What was the name of the king of Magadh during this time?
What was the capital city of Magadh?
How old was Sthulibhadra when he left home to live with Koshä?
How old was Sthulibhadra when he renounced the world?
quizData.answer: He was 30 years old (after spending 12 years with Koshä).

children.name: The Monsoon Test in Koshä's palace

graphicsData.title: A Life of Indulgence
graphicsData.description: For twelve years, the young Sthulibhadra abandons his duties and lives a life of pleasure with the beautiful dancer, Koshä.
graphicsData.imageAlt: A young nobleman and a beautiful dancer in a lavishly decorated room.

graphicsData.title: The Awakening
graphicsData.description: The tragic news of his father's death shatters Sthulibhadra's world, forcing him to confront the emptiness of his life and seek a new path.
graphicsData.imageAlt: Sthulibhadra looking at his own reflection with a look of shock and realization.

graphicsData.title: The Ultimate Test
graphicsData.description: To conquer his past desires, Monk Sthulibhadra spends four months meditating in the palace of his former lover, Koshä, who tries to win him back.
graphicsData.imageAlt: A monk meditating peacefully while a beautiful woman tries to get his attention.

graphicsData.title: The Failed Imitator
graphicsData.description: To teach a jealous monk a lesson, Koshä asks him for a gift, which he foolishly brings, only for her to toss it away to show him the value of what he is throwing away: his monkhood.
graphicsData.imageAlt: A woman scornfully throwing a valuable garment in the trash as a monk looks on in disbelief.

graphicsData.title: Seeking the Last Master
graphicsData.description: To preserve the complete scriptures after a famine, Sthulibhadra journeys to Nepal to learn from Ächärya Bhadrabähu, the last person who knows them all.
graphicsData.imageAlt: A monk traveling through a mountainous landscape.

graphicsData.title: The Lion's Prank
graphicsData.description: Sthulibhadra misuses his powers by turning into a lion to scare his sisters, a trivial act for which his guru, Bhadrabähu, chastises him.
graphicsData.imageAlt: Two nuns looking frightened at the entrance of a cave where a lion is sitting.
